tagDescription: to George Garden. Report of law proceedings concerning Lord Selkirk's arrest.Extraordinary behaviour of Judge Woodward. Interference of the Attorney-General.
to Lady Selkirk. Fort William prosecution to be continued at Sandwich. Piller to be examined regarding the execution of McNab's warrant. His own health improving.
to Dickson. Letters forward. General Report.
to Lady Selkirk,(French.) Expressing his gratitude to Lord Selkirk.
to J.B.Robinson. Referring to validity in Upper Canada of warrants issued in Lower Canada,as in the case of James Mc Intosh.
to Matthey.(Copy.) Agreement on his appointment as Superintendent at Red River.
to de Graffenried. Forwards letter and book from his friends in Switzerland.
Bishop Plessis(French.). Circular letter to clergy of his diocese.
to Colonel Cockburn. Requesting information rgarding government supplies for disbanded soldiers and military settlements at Drummondville and Perth.

to J.Allan. Enclose copy of Detroit Gazette containing Allan's communication. Editors will receive articles on the subject of the North West Company trials.Considers it well that the trials did not take place at York.Detroit lawyers had been engaged against Lord Selkirk.Prosecution against Smith.

to Selkirk. Gives a general report.Considers young Innes suitable for an Indian trader.Describes new calumnies and aggressions.Hopes his Memorial will be successful.Wishes him a prosperous voyage to England.
to Selkirk,(French.) Cases of books delivered to de Lorimier.
to Roderick McKay. Is pleased that Mr.Washburn has been retained. Dr.Allan at York.
to Selkirk.(French.) Stating terms on which he is willing to settle in Red River colony.
to Bathurst.(Copy.) Encloses copy of instructions from Hudson's Bay Company to Governors and others relating to Commissiones.  Enclosures:-
Athabasca Evidence. Affidavits from George Innes,Etienne St.Pierre, Ignace Perrault, Hector McNeil.John McLeod. Toussaint Pacquin, Ferdinand Chelli.
to Selkirk. Referring to the Earl's requests that Crown Lawyers should consult with his own counsel.
Selkirk's Memorandum. References to be made on Reinhard case as to limits between Upper Canada and the Indian Territories.
to John Allan. On matters relating to affairs of Lord Selkirk.
to Lady Selkirk. Forwards note for £700 to be signed by Lord Selkirk.
to Selkirk. Report on estate and family matters.
to Lady Selkirk. Warrants were sent by Gauvin. Simpson undertakes to furnish his notes each day. Will undertake to learn shorthand writing himself. Mentions matters relating to the trials.
to Selkirk. Seeking pecuniary assistance in a personal difficulty.
Second warrant regarding the search for arms and papers.
to Selkirk. Explaining the reasons for liberation of Cuthbert Grant on bail.Refers to the other cases to be tried in Upper Canada.
to Colonel Addison. Regarding pay for the detachment of the 37th Regiment forming an escort, 1816.
to Selkirk. Inquires whether Captain de Lorimier,who was sent with the Missionaries at Red River is in his employ or in that of the Hudson's Bay Company.
to Selkirk. Explains reasons for closing the Court 20 April.

to John Aallan. Charge of partiality against the magistrates dismissed by the Court. Witnesses to be present at the beginning of February.The Jurisdiction Bill has passed and become a law.Lord Selkirk likely to be compelled to attend and answer charges to be proferred.
to Selkirk. Encloses petition to the Lords of the Treasury with certificates.Formerly had charge of the naval establishment on Lake Huron. Enclosures:-
Private communication to Huerter on the subject of settlers for Red River.
to Gale. Referring to the falsities of the North West depositions.Simpson's notes of Robertson's trial.Fears North West Company will seek proclamation for general pardon of their offences.
to Selkirk. Has written to Henry McKenzie for Red River account books.
to Selkirk. Is ready to proceed on Bill of Indictment.
to Robinson. Forwarding affidavits from McDonald and Pritchard. Refers to Vandersluys and McTavish regarding Lord Selkirk's conduct at Fort William.
to Angus Shaw.(Copy.) Regarding the capture of Robertson by Black.Difficulty of getting him out of Athabasca into Canada.
to Selkirk. Announcing the arrival of himself and the missionaries. The settlers well and the crops good.
to Selkirk. Further news on the estate.

to Lady Selkirk. Forwards affidavit regarding the personal assault on him by McLellan.Decision of the Court on the Transference of the trials.Petition regarding the Attorney General's jurisdiction. The Governor's attitude.
to Selkirk. Has no warrants in his possession against those indicted by the Montreal Court.
to LeMoine, (French.) General instructions.
to Robinson. Acknowledges receipt of his letter of 15 August.Refers to transfer of trials to Upper Canada,and such further steps as may be necessary.
to Selkirk. No necessity for trials to take place in England.Chief Justice Sewell's opinion.
to Selkirk. States amount paid Dr.Scott at Baldoon in 1804.
to J.Allan. Lord Selkirk's commissions as a Justice of the Peace for the Indian Territories received. Forwarded copies of various affidavits obtained from Mr.Robinson.
to Selkirk. Acknowledges his letter and declines to prosecute Major Fletcher.
to Selkirk. Returning copies of intercepted letters. Gives reasons for not signing the enclosed certificate.
to Justice of the Peace,Sandwich. Explaining his inability to appear at the Quarter Sessions;requests that his recognizance may stand over for another term.
to T.Wright. Regarding Captain Alex.McMillan's land on Belfast Creek,Prince Edward Island.
Instructions from Hudson's Bay Company to all Governors in the Indian Territory.
to Selkirk. Encloses letters from Johnston on his affairs in Prince Edward Island.
to Selkirk. Hopes to be retained in the Company's service.

to Lady Selkirk. Continuing his account of Court proceedings. Considers the Attorney-General a curse to the Province.The Solicitor-General infinitely better.Fears further delay in settling the trials.
to J.Allan. Regarding the conduct of the Grand Jury on the North West trials.
to P.P.La Croix. Encloses letters alluded to. Instructions given regarding lot for his occupation.
to Selkirk. Referring to trials taking place at York in October. Measures adopted for removing prisoners from Montreal.
to Selkirk. Hopes to be relieved so that he may go home.Thinks of taking land for a farm. Red River affairs in good order.
to J.Livingston. Urging him to come to Canada as a settler.
to Selkirk. Considers Spence and Pambrun unfit for settlers.Encloses copy of a letter to Thomas Vincent for the construction of a boat.
to Uniacke. As Cuthbert Grant is at Quebec hopes he will be arrested and sent to Upper Canada,with Campbell,Brown and Boucher,to appear before the Court.
to Selkirk.(French.) Gives favourable report of the Mission established at Red River; the crops and general state of affairs.
to J.Allan. Has found Dr.Strachan's letter so long mislaid. Hints that a Bill is being prepared against Lord Selkirk for assault on Smith.
to Coltman. Request for Day_Book to be delivered to Mr.McKenzie.
to Uniacke. Forwards copy of Captain Matthey's letter.Has no means nor authority to interfere further.
to J.Craig. Requesting him to ascertain from the United-Sates Government if a passport could be obtained through their Indian Territory to Red River.
to Selkirk. Memorandum of affidavits.Names and charges given.
A list of the crew and passengers of seven canoes intended for the Red River Settlement.Names,occupation and effects given.
Certificate of Indictments found at Montreal. (Copy.) Names given. (Nos.1-7)
to Coltman. Requests him to sign the revised certificate on affairs at Red River.
List of indictments against the North West Company for aggressions against the Red River settlers.Names and charges given. Articles written for the Canadian Courant on this subject.
to Gale. Gives instructions regarding Allan,Pritchard,Huerter and Pambrun who are to come to England on conclusion of proceedings at York;would have Joseph Parisien come with them.
to J.Greig. Referring to the boundary line and sale of Red River lands.Sketch of tract to be sold and terms of sale.

to Selkirk. Enclosing protest from the North West Company against their building on the bank of the river.The post not supplied with trading goods. Complains that he was accused of telling a falsehood on what took place at the massacre at Frederick House.Remarks on the ill-treatment he received on board the Eddystone. Signifies his desire to leave the Company.
to Uniacke. Referring to the removal of Campbell,Brown,and Boucher to Upper Canada.
to Thomas Clarke. Informing him of Lord Selkirk's desire for his services in actions brought by D.McKenzie and William Smith.
to Selkirk. Referring to the jurisdiction to be given to Upper Canada for trial of Simon McGillivray. Application should be made to Government of Lower Canada.
to C.Bagot. Refers to and espresses annoyance, at anonymous letters said to be his appearing in American Press.Authorizes contradiction.
to Selkirk. Indian Territory warrants being prepared.Campbell, Brown,and Boucher being transferred to Upper Canada.
to James Woods. Memorandum of letter relating to two lots on the Thames River. Court at York set for 15 July. Fort William not in Canada.
to George Ridout. Is concerned regarding date for holding Court; fears delay.
to Selkirk. Acknowledges letter of 8th instant.Refers him to the Attorney-General.
to the Lords of the Treasury.(Copy.) Petition for a position in some public office.
to Lady Selkirk. Remarks on the trial and the termination. The Petition of the Assembly has fallen through. The Bishop's Circular letter to the Cures.
to Gale. Is sending his daily notes on the evidence given at the trial.
First warrant issued by Lord Selkirk against North West Company.
to Selkirk. Subtance of a letter on colony settlement and affairs.

to Lady Selkirk. Forwards some sheets of Simpson's report of the evidence;also a copy of his letter to Coltman.Fears fresh outrages may be committed by the Brules. Coltman's observations on overtures made in February.
to W.S.Simpson. Expresses regret that he should feel hurt by letter being sent through Mr.Allan.

to Sir Peregrive Maitland. Lays before him copies of an affidavit by S.Gale on the conduct of John Fletcher,Joseph Vandersluys and J.C.McTavish.Protests against proceedings in Sandwich Court. Considers that there is no necessity nor obligation for him to remain in "these Provinces."
to William Elliot. Instructions to have the case of the Deputy Sheriff transferred to the Assizes.
to Col.Cochran. Referring to Lord Selkirk's letter of 13 April to Sherbrooke.
to Selkirk. Regarding William,(his nephew) and his desire to go to Red River.
to Mrs.Keveny.(Copy.) Lord Selkirk not responsible for the death of her son. All claims for remuneration settled.
to John Allan. Referring to Paul Biba's deposition. Is willing to give any explanation of his own proceeding.Asks for private copy of Hudson's Bay Company's Charter.
to Lady Selkirk. Informing her on Court Proceedins.
to Lady Selkirk. Advising her of the colony and state of the Mission. (French.)
to Selkirk. Telling a discreditable anecdote of Major Fletcher in 1812. Report that Duke of Richmond is appointed Governor-in-Chief.
to Selkirk(French.) General report on affairs at Red River.
to Selkirk. The Court of Oyer and Terminer closed for want of witnesses in North West Company trials.Postponed to October.
to Selkirk. Will report on Reinhard's trial and the question of jurisdiction to the Colonial Secretary.
to Uniacke. Regarding the date of the York Court of Oyer and Terminer.

to Lady Selkirk. Bill found against Paul Brown for robbery.Sherwood's objections to accessories after the fast.Proposals to question Great Britain's right to confer jurisdiction on Upper Canada Courts;probable effect.Jurisdiction Bill to come before the House on the 28th instant.Encloses copy of Dr.Allan's deposition respecting longitude of Fort William.
to J.B.Robinson. Unable to return to York for the trials;his absence provided for.
Return to Bill of Indictment against Lord Selkirk and others.
to Selkirk. General report of his journey and conditions at Red River.(French.)
Bishop Plessis. Instructions to Messrs.J.N. Provencher and S.J.N.Doumoulin,missionaries nominated for the Indian Territories at Red River.
to Selkirk. Delayed, but hopes to proceed with Forrest of LaCroiz.

to Selkirk. Refers to original information given by Vandersluys and McTavish.Mr. Ireland,from York, appointed clerk of the Peace for the District.Dr.Richardson has received his land at Chatham.Will take the other two lots himself,one at Dover,and one at Chatham.
to Uniacke. Acknowledges his letter of the 6th instant.Further remarks on the trials in U.C. Reinhart and McLellan waiting trial.
to Sherbrooke. Forwarding a copy of Captain Matthey's letter of the 17th instant.
to Selkirk. Removal of Campbell,Boucher and Brown from Montreal.

to Selkirk. Reports his arrival with the brigade on the 24 July. Returns to Athabasca;eighteen have left for that part.Has reduced Clarke's jurisdiction.Colony affairs.Necessity for goods necessary for the Canadians of the Athabasca department. de Graffenried caused great expense at Fort Daer.Complaints against Governor of Colony by Officers.
to Sherbrooke. Acknowledging receipt of letters referring to his proposal for employing extra Crown Counsel.
to Selkirk. Remarks on the North West Company trials.
to Selkirk. Suggests settlers going to Red River via the Mississippi River; that people from Louisiana might emigrate. John O'Rourke would return with some good settlers if encouraged.
to Lady Selkirk. Informing her of his visit to Mr.Taschereau.Remarks on Coltman's defence of Lord Bathurst's partiality.Simpson has agreed to go to Montreal with him.
to------Fowler,Newport,kentucky. Arrangements for providing cattle for the Red River Settlement.
to Allan. Ordinance of Congress shows Fond du Lac within United States territory;asks for proof.Effect on Canadian Magistrates jurisdiction.
to Duke of Richmond. A memorial on the subject of the crimes committed in the Indian Territories to be submitted to him.
to George Garden. Referring to a memorandum of provisions for Red River. Suggests taking up sheep and lambs. A millwright to be sent.Would have August Bouche sent to England as a witness.
to Sherbrooke. Expresses doubt as to jurisdiction of Quebec Court in trial of Reinhart and McLellan.

to Selkirk. Acknowledges letter and retainer received.Refers to the trials at York. Not prepared to give an opinion on Dr. Strachan's qualification. Pamphlets containing newspaper articles by Maulins and Mercator circulated.
to Selkirk. Reports his arrival and that of Mr.Forrest with despatches from Red River and a favourable account of the Settlement.Dousman to deliver the cattle.
to Lady Selkirk. Account of journey and matters connected with North West Company trials.

to C.O.Ermatinger. Trials of the North West Company postponed to October. Requests his attendance at Sandwich for the trials. Would offer Colonel Dickson passage in the canoe for Red River. Refers to the practicability of driving cattle to the Settlement.
to Colvile. Personal affairs.Instructions for £90 to be paid to Neil Livingston to replace the amount sent by Donald Livingston which was lost in the Britannia.
to Selkirk. Informing him that recognizances of the seven men taken in Montreal have been transmitted to Upper Canada.
to Sherbrooke. Points out the disadvantage of Crown Counsels imperfect knowledge of French.Suggests additional nomination.
to Plesses.(French.) Referring to the Missionaries proceeding to Red River Settlement.
Boundaries of Canada according to the Chief Justice.
to Lady Selkirk. Reinhard's trial commenced on the 22nd instant.Gives particulars of proceedings.
to J.Miller. In reply to his of 27 January.Appointing him agent for lands on the Salmon River.Asks information regarding his land at the mouth of Grand River on Lake Erie,with a view to settling it.

to Selkirk. The arrival of the Roman Catholic priests in Red River has given general satisfaction to the colony. Has prepared goods for an outfit to Pembina. Scarcity of provisions.Has been requested to spend the winter at Cumberland House with Mr.Bird. Hopes to have a house built for him at Red River.
to Gale. Regarding the charges of perjury laid by him against Vandersluys and James McTavish.
to Selkirk. (French.) Regarding Captain de Lorimier accompanying the Missionnaries to Red River.
to Selkirk. Gives an account of his proceedings. Success of previous winter.
to Gale. The Bois Brules give evidence. Sewell,Chief Justice, likely to give a charge in McLellan's favour.

to Lady Selkirk. In his opinion nothing is to be gained by sending warrants into the interior. Suggests Lord Selkirk write Lord Bathurst stating the obstacles raised by Crown Officers.Has received Simpson's notes on the Judge's charge.
to Selkirk. Acknowledges the receipt of Captain Matthey's letter relating to his return to Red River.
to R. Christie. Informing him G.P.Andries deposition must be taken before Mr.Coltman.
to Lady Selkirk. Mentioning a young man named Inglis who might settle at Red River. Messrs.Berezy,Maen & Co. will undertake the agency for Lord Selkirk at Sandwich.Refers to His Lordship's Memorial.
to Selkirk. Seeks adjustment of claim for injury sustained by the American Fur Company from arrest of Mr.Morrison.
to Selkirk. Forward express from Fort Douglas. Is unable to carry on trade where he is.Has communicated with Mr.Bird concerning the trade.Found 605 buffalo robes at Mr. Graham's house.
to Uniacke. Regrets information as to time set for trials in Upper Canada.
to de Lorimier. (French.) Referring to engagement of certain Iroquois as guides.
to Gale. Returning deposition made by him against Major Fletcher.
to Selkirk. Enclosing joint letter from Uniacke and Marshall.
to J.B.Robinson. Regarding the special sessions for the trials of the North West Company's men.
to Selkirk. Further report on affairs at Red River.
to Selkirk. Reports arrival. Instructions from Governor Bird as to holding the Post. Went to Lake of the Woods for provisions.
Bishop Plessis to Selkirk. (French.) Referring to his instructions to the Missionaries going to Red River.
to William Jonston. Replying to his of 31 March.Instrusts him to place Captain Alex.McMillan and Thomas Halliday in possession of their lands.
to Lady Selkirk. Giving account of his journey as far.
to Lady Selkirk. Reports to the progress of the country. Informs her of his attachment to a Miss McDonald, and his hopes of advancement that will enable him to marry.
to Selkirk. Letters received.Refers to his own letters and enclosures.Long report of affairs in general.
to Selkirk. Sentence of death passed on de Reinhard. Gives account of proceedings.

to John Pritchard. States that the propriety of subpoena for Mr.Mondelet be submitted to the Attorney-General.Wishes to be informed whether the Attorney General of Lower Canada has issued instruments under the Great Seal for the trial of Brown for robbery at Lake St.Charles in 1805.
to Selkirk. Gives account os estate and farm news.
to Uniacke. Suggesting that the government offer a reward for the apprehension of Cuthbert Grant.
to Selkirk. (French.) Referring to the Red River Mission.
to Coltman. Forwards Captain Matthey's letter of the 7th instant.

to Allan. Acknowledges letter and papers returned.Regrets North West Company should have given passages to the Indian country to persons under indictment.Results of trials even less satisfactory to North West Company than to Hudson's Bay Company.Forwards correspondance between Lord Selkirk and himself.
to Lady Selkirk. Trial of Siveright and others for the murder of Governor Semple ends in acquittal. Lord Selkirk to sail from New York. Forwards minutes relating to the lasst trial.
to Selkirk. Will arrange to go with him to York. Publication received and will be circulated.
to Gale. Considers his presence indispensable in Upper Canada.
to Uniacke. Names witnesses availbale to substantiate indictments.
to Cochran. Considers it unnecessary to nominate further Crown Counsel.
to Gale. Proceedings and evidence of North West Company witnesses.
to Lady Sherbrooke. Referring to the release of McLellan,Grant and Cadotte on bail;considers it likely to have a bad effect in the province.Reasons for transfer of trial to Quebec.
to Ermatinger. Letters received. Rate paid in wages to men from Point Meuron to Red River.Provisions needed.
to D.S.Kennedy. Requesting him to enquire for a good shorthand writer. Query about indictment signed by a private barrister.
to de Graffenried. Advises him to return to Europe by way Hudson Bay.
to A.Colvile. Requesting passages for fifty or sixty families intending to settle at Red River.
to Selkirk. Informing him of farm work done on his estate.
to Lord Selkirk. Charge for short-hand notes.
to Coltman. With reference to Lord Selkirk's refusal to consent to agreement proposed by the Commissioners in February; disinterested persons approve of His Lordship's conduct.
to J.J.Astor. Acknowledges letter respecting the seizure of James Grant and William Morrison. Is willing to refer the matter to arbritation.
to Selkirk. Remarks on Smith's prosecution of Dr.Allan. Bill passed to change venue of Indian Territories trials.Asks for a decision on the two lots applied for.Could secure good settlers.
to J.B.Robinson. Forwards affidavit of James Mc Intosh against Simon McGillivray,Henry McKenzie and James Chisholm McTavish. Asks for information relating to proceedings against John Fletcher.
to J.B.Robinson. Enclosing affidavit of James McIntosh against Simon McGillivray and others. Inquires when proceedings commence against Major Fletcher.
to Coltman. Forwards the original pledges made at Red River,7 July, 1817.Hears that North West murderers have returned to the interior and fears for settlers.
to Lady Selkirk. Meeting and adjournment of Court.
to Gale, Informing him of court proceedings in McLellan's case. Attorney and Solitor General's opinion regarding Coltman's jurisdiction. Christie has written unlacks about Shaw's case.

Dr. Samuel Peters.Memorandum regarding Colonel Robert Dickson's arrest by order of Lt-Colonel William Chambers,in April 1817;his marriage to Madam Elisabeth Weenow; charges against him,trial and discharge.
to Gale. McLellan's trial proceeding. Coltman's evidence regarding Fort William as within the American Boundary.
to Samuel Smith.(Copy.) Requesting him to recomment the Attorney General taking assistance of his counsel in North West trials.
to Coltman. Presents his compliments and returns the Process-Verbal of the Indian Council on the massacre of 19 June,with revisions indicated.
to Selkirk. Reopening of Court for North West Company trials.
to Selkirk. Trials to take place in Upper Canada.

to Selkirk. Informing him of a plague of grasshoppers which invaded the crops on the 2nd instant. There is not a vestige of barley or the potatoes left. Mr.Shaw of the North West Company passed through on the 13th.He is to endeavour to keep the peace and is to proceed to England to make a report on the state of the country.
to Gale. Has closed agreement with Simpson for shorthand notes.
to Sherbrooke. References to de Reinhard's case.
to J.B.Robinson. Asking him to defend in civil action brought against him by Daniel McKenzie and William Smith for false imprisonment.
to George Ridout. Memorandum of letter relating to date of Oyer and Terminer. Accomodation for witnesses.Enquire for residence of John and Alex.Murray,H.McLeod,and H.Sutherland, good witnesses.
to F.W.Ermantinger. Warrants for persons in the Indian Territories.

to Selkirk. Gives a general report on affairs in Athabasca.Clarke, Robertson and others going to Montreal.Colonel Dickson giving up his trade and leaving the country.Confusion existing between the Red River Settlement and the Hudson's Bay Company. The ship Britannia destroyed by fire last May with the greater part of her cargo.Captain Edmonds ill with scurvey;the ship in charge of the mate.Many deaths from scurvey.Mr.William Sinclair died at York Factory. Will fit out a very complete and powerful brigade for Athabasca.Account of furs sent to Red River for de Lorimier.
Agents for the North West Company. Protest against trespass on their property by the Hudson's Bay Company at Lac La Pluie.
Bishop Plessis. Pastoral Letter to Canadians at Red River.
to Selkirk. Describes affairs in the Colony. Settlers pleased and cultivating their lots.
to Uniacke. Referring to insinuations made by Henry McKenzie to J. B.Lapointe,one of the Crown witnesses.
to Bishop Plessis.(French.) Aid from England for the Roman Catholic Mission at Red River. Mentions the probability of a Bishopric for Upper Canada.
to Mr.Washburn. Expressing his pleasure that he has been retained on account of the Hudson's Bay Co.

to Selkirk(French.) Referring to Indian traders anxious to settle at Red River.Considers their services valuable. Names the following as desirable:William,Augustin ,and Louis Grignon,W. Powell,T.Law and F.Caron.
to Selkirk. Referring to Andries deposition before Coltman.
to Allan. Gives his favourable opinion on Lord Selkirk's Observations on the situation between te two companies.
to R.Dickson, (French.) Forwards personal letters. Gives an account of Post affairs. Two of his men arrested by Doctor McLaughlin of North West Company. Scarvity of provisions.

to Selkirk. Arrival of Matthey's brigade.Letters received.Prospects better for the harvest.Canadians settlers go on to Pembina.Mentions Dr. White's account. Necessity of his returning to England next season.
(Glenallnadale.) to Selkirk. Referring to affairs on the Island. Demand of the Lieut. Governor for payment of quit rents.
to Uniacke. Again referring to warrants for persons in the Indian Territories.
to Coltman. Certificate unnecessary if facts are to be fully noticed in his report to the government.
to de Lorimier. (French.) Forwarding copy of a letter received from North West Company by Sir John Sherbrooke.
to Selkirk. Letter of 20 July received. Petitions signed by Scotch settlers. Remarks on the movements of the Indians. Many coming in for the winter. Duncan Graham to winter in the Sioux country.
to Selkirk. Referring to the probability of forming a Campany to purchase his lands at Red River.
Affidavit regarding Selkirk and the North West Co. case.
to Selkirk. Has been left in charge of Post by LeMoine.Necessary to rebuild the blockhouse. Asks for instructions.
(Copy.) Instructions for engaging labourers for Red River;wages and land granted to each.
to Uniacke. Stressing the urgency of Sheriff's obtaining warrants for persons in the Indians Territories.
to Selkirk. Informing him of Gale's departure.His own and d'Orsonnens evidence against McTavish.

to Selkirk. Gives an account of his journey,the brigade and colony affairs. Remarks on the enormous herds of buffalo. Crops injured by the early frosts; but the present season promises a luxuriant harvest. Hears from his father in Scotland that many new settlers desire to come to the Settlement. Gives account of grain sown.
to Selkirk.(French.) Expressing his desire to become a settler at Red River.
to Selkirk. Wishes to proceed to Red River to join his two brothers.
to Selkirk. Places £300 in the hands of Mr.Moffat for his orphan niece.
to Colin Robertson, Advising him that Daniel Washburn of Kingston had been retained for the Hudson's Bay Company.
to Selkirk. Acknowledging arrival of books and in circulation.Trials to take place in October.
to Selkirk. Referring to a box he has had no oppurtunity to forward. Carriage left with Taylor has been sold.
to Selkirk. Has received good accounts from the Red River.Many Indians wish to proceed to the Colony from the United Sates. Morrison,who escaped from Sault St.Mary,is at this place.
Recognizance in the Court of King's Bench.
to Lady Selkirk. Informs her that Lord Selkirk's arrest on a Sunday is not valid.
Sworn deposition against Major John Fletcher.

to Lady Selkirk. Enclosing the Chief Justice's remarks on the boundaries of Upper Canada in which he establishes the Pacific Ocean as the Western boundary. Interference of Attorney-General of Upper Canada. Bill of Indictment against Lord Selkirk in the House of Assembly. Protest entered. Dickson's use of it.
to Allan. Requests a list of the names of Brules said to have returned to Red River.
to Selkirk. Favourable accounts received from Red River.many settlers coming in spring. Good results from the establishment of a church.
to Selkirk. Reports arrival and gives long account of the journey. Movements of brigade. Buffalo reported very plentiful; crops good.McNaulty and his family at the Sault.
to Selkirk. Draft of certificate.
to John McVicar. Power of Attorney to collect £90.
to John Mcvicar. Power of Attorney to collect £90.
to Andrew Colvile. Regarding Lord Selkirk's Red River business.
Charles Douglas Smith, Lt-Governor of Prince Edward Island. Proclamation regarding Quit Rents.
to Gale. Remarks on LaPointe's cross-examination.
Certifies to the character of Thomas Cranstoun.
to Selkirk. Report of affairs on the estate.
to Selkirk. Cases against Grant and Lamarre transformed to Upper Canada.
Recognizance in the Court of the King's Bench.
to Lady Selkirk. Grand Jury brought in true bill against Reinhard and others for Keveny's murder.
to Lady Selkirk. Returns to Montreal as no Court in session at present.
to J.B.Robinson. Time set for trials of North West Company partners and servants.
to Lady Selkirk. Has been to Court and seen the North Westerners present. Awaits the result of the trials.
to Selkirk. Decline signing the certificate.

to Selkirk. Regarding trade with the Indians.Dickson's disqualifications.Arrangements with Rainville completed. Will endeavour to obtain specimens of any minerals known to the Indians. Report of his own movements.
to Selkirk. Has arranged to sell lot No.10.Hopes for his approval.
to Selkirk, Giving an account of his management and the lands in Belfast Settlement.
to J.B.Robinson. Expresses his thanks for explanation in closing the Court in April.

to Selkirk. Regarding the construction of a boat on Lake Superior for the transportation of supplies.The Hudson's Bay Company ship Eddystone anchored at Moose Roads on the 16 August with supplies,and sailed on 10 September for England.
to Selkirk. Regarding pay for the military escort from the 37th Regiment.
Dr. Samuel Peters to Selkirk. Forwards a memorandum on capture of Colonel Dickson.

to Uniacke. Replying to his of 16 May.Questions the fact of Cuthbert Grant's release on bail. Reported that others had been granted bail in January. Cases referred to Court of Upper Canada. Gives reasons for addressing His Majesty's Government through the Governor-in-Chief in Canada.
to lady Selkirk. Further account of Reinhard's trial. Considers Miles MacDonell and Colin Robertson Lord Selkirk's real enemies.
to Selkirk.(French.) Has drawn for balance of his pay.
to Coltman. Court at Quebec rules that Fort William is in the United States. Is returning to Red River as there is no charge against him.
to Stewart. Will undertake the charge of Lord Selkirk's affairs.
to Bishop Plessis. (French.) Papers relating to the departure of two canoes received. Supplies for the Missionaries.
to Colonel Troup. Replying to his of 14 February.Refers to death of Colonel Walker.Will appoint M.S.Miller,agent of Salmon River estate on his recommendation.
to Sherbrooke. Regarding the warrants for the arrest of persons still in the Indian Territories.

to Selkirk. Report his arrival from Montreal,and his journey with the brigade. de Lorimier left with the Missionaries a few days previous. Harmony at Fond du Lac between colonists and natives. Colonel Dickson's packs seized in United States territory. Families anxious to settle at Red River. Supplies provided for Missionaries.
to Sherbrooke. Assuring him that de Lorimier was never in his or the Hudson's Bay Company employ.
to A.W.Cochran. Regarding Judges of the Court of Oyer and Terminer.
to Selkirk. Replies to letter of 14 March regarding the transfer of the trials to Upper Canada.
and Ogden. Warrant for the liberation of George Campbell,halfbreed,employed by the North West Company.
to Selkirk. Informing him that the North West trials are set for October.
to James Woods. Enclosing copy of his letter to McNab.
to A.Mundell. Acknowledges his letter addressed to Lord Bathurst.
to Gale. Quebec proceedings in Reinhard's case.
to A.W.Cochran. (Copy.) Referring to the trials of Reinhart and McLellan.No doubt as to jurisdiction in Canada.
Memorandum in answer to the declaration of McGillivray and others.
to Selkirk. Acknowledges letter of 13 February,and accompanying despatches.Statement not yet received from publishers. One hundred copies of the sketch to cost $100.
to Lady Selkirk. Encloses copy of his letter to Coltman,and his reply regarding the Brules. Indictment against Captain Matthey.Report of an interview with Colonel Coltman on the same matter.
Recognizance in the Court of King's Bench.
to Lady Selkirk. Account of his journey to Montreal.
to Coltman.(Copy.) Adverse opinion regarding his granting the certificate to Lord Selkirk relating to his mission in the Indian Territories.
to Selkirk. Advising him that affidavits of Red River deserters,taken in 1816,have been handed over to George Ridout.
to Selkirk. Regarding arrangements with Pritchard and other witnesses sent home. Sale of Fort William furs as no longer required as evidence.

to Neil Livingston. Had sent £90 to assist him in his passage to Canada; fears the money was lost in the ship which was burnt in Hudson Bay. Sends Power of Attorney to J.McVicar, Islay.Urging him to bring many articles for use in the Settlement.
to Selkirk. Reports the movements of the Brigade under Lemoine;reports the latter is determined to return to Montreal.
to Selkirk. Claim for damage done at Fond du Lac. Forwards account by Mr.Crooks,the agent, who will receive payment.

to Selkirk. Reports arrival.All in good health.Crops ruined by grasshoppers. Wheat in perfect shape.Settlers from Orkney had arrived. There are 151 Scotch with twenty houses built; 45 de Meurons,31 houses; 26 Canadians,6 houses. All deserve praise for their industry.Indians active.
to Selkirk(French.) Arrival of Captain Matthey with his brigade. Report of the Colony.
to John McNab. Regarding the lots issued to him by patent in the Townships of Dover and Chatham.
to Selkirk. Report of journey and arrival of canoes.Will remain at the Post. de Lorimier will give and account of the Colony.
to J.B.Robinson. Enclosing a list of witnesses in the Indian Territory cases.Decision on the western limits of Upper Canada.
to d'Orsonnens.(French.) Enclosing a token of his friendship. Will arrange a free passage for him to Switzerland.
to Selkirk. Men leaving for Montreal.McKenzie's evidence against North West Company regarding Fort Wedderburn in 1816-17.Contracts with Canadians all expiring.
to Bishop Plessis. Arrangements for the Catholic Mission to proceed to Red River. De Lorimier should accompany it. Trustee should be appointed.
to Gale. Account of Court proceedings.Grant's recognizance. Simpson refuses notes until settlement made.
to Lady Selkirk. Further information on Court proceedings and examinations.Expects verdict to be given the next day.
to Selkirk. Enclosing printer's account for Statement and Sketch of the Fur trade.
to J. Portier. Replying to his of 22 August,and referring him to Colonel Dickson for information.
to Selkirk. Regarding Grant's arrest.Gives account of Court proceedings.
to Selkirk. Enquiry as to pay for Sergeant Pugh and others of 37th Regiment.
to Selkirk. Gives general report; provisions, stores,furs,etc.

to Bathurst. As Law agent for Lord Selkirk enquires as to his position with reference to the boundary treaty with the United States. Seeks protection in case any part of the Hudson's Bay Charter for land should be ceded to the United States.
to Selkirk. Report of affairs on the estate.
to J.B.Robinson. Regarding subpoenas required for witnesses to appear at the York Court of Oyer and Terminer.Hopes for early session of the Court.
to Selkirk. Informing him regarding the opening of the Court of Oyer and Terminer at York.
to de Graffenried. Is hopeful of success at last.
to Uniacke. Referring to the trials in Upper Canada.Witnesses against Cuthbert Grant and others ready.
to Uniacke. Will forward documents in his possession relating to Campbell,Brown,and Boucher to the Attorney-General of Upper Canada.
to Selkirk. Further comments on the matter of the certificate.Refers to Mr.Allan's deposition.
to Sir P.Maitland. Refers to Bill affecting legal rights of His Majesty's subjects not now in Canada.

to Selkirk. Acknowledges letter of 9 December and the seeds.The horses very poor.Has two oxen,two cows,a heifer and bull brought from Lac La Pluie. Impossible to get any sledges made.Attaches an account of grain found at Bas de la Riviere;also oats and potatoes.
to Selkirk. Recommends Mr.Emmet as barrister. The shorthand writer undecided as to leaving New York.
to Selkirk. Encloses copies of his pastoral letter to Red River Colonists. (French.) No enclosures.
to Alex.McMillan. Acknowledges his letter of 24 May, 1817,just received. Has given instructions for his land to be placed at his disposal.
to Selkirk. Replying to his of the 16th instant.No new Crown Councel to be appointed.
to Mr.Robertson. Report of journey. Has retained Mr.Washburn.General information as to forthcoming trials. Date of Quarter Sessions.
to Uniacke. Informing him that persons indicted are presumed to be under his control as they are in custody.
to Selkirk. Informing him that the President considers intercourses between United States and Red River unfavourably.
to J.B.Robinson. Acknowledges letters received and forwards affidavits relative to the cases of Campbell,Brown,and Boucher with particulars.
to Selkirk. Replying to his letter of the 5th instant with reference to publication of anonymous letters.
to Matthey. Regarding de Reinhard.
to Andrew Maitland. Refers to affairs at Red River. The present Agent there is returning to England. Farming operations are in charge of Mr.Laidlaw.Scotch settlers very troublesome.
to Selkirk. An account of estate affairs.
to George Garden. Instructions for supplying the Red River Settlement with tobacco and provisions.
to A.W.Cochran. (Copy.) Observations on Lord Selkirk's letter of May 16 to the Governor-in-Chief,as directed against himself.
to Uniacke. Complies with his request and particularises the case of Cuthbert Grant for murder of R.Semple in 1816.
Bishop Plessis. Authorization for founding a Mission at Red River.
to James Stewart. Requesting him to take charge of his affairs in Prince Edward Island and select an Agent to carry out instructions. Gives an account of his land.
to North West Company. Requesting the delivery of Red River account books to Captain Matthey.
to Sherbrooke. Reasons against the trials taking place in Upper Canada. Wishes to assist the Attorney-General.
to Lady Selkirk. Gives account of his journey and trial. Interference by Deputy Sheriff Smith.Complaints should be made to the Governer regarding the improper conduct of the Crown Officers.
to Sherbrooke. (Copy.) Laying before him copies of petition from persons indicted asking speedy settlement of their trials.

to Uniacke. The Attorney-General of Upper Canada doubts the validity of instruments transmitting the North West trials to that province.Courts may interpret adversely as to jurisdiction and cognisances conferred.
to Selkirk. (French.) Expressing him his gratitude for the assistance given the Mission at Red River.
to Captain Stephens. Referring to full pay for men of 37th Regiment forming an escort.
to Gale. Encloses certificate require. McLellan arranged by order of the Court. Warrant sent against McLeod and MacDonell by Coltman. Considers Simpson's rates as stenographer unreasonable.
to Selkirk. Regarding his right to a quarry at Belfast, P.E.I.
to Sherbrooke. Protesting against the principle laid down by the Attorney-General. Gives particulars.
to Selkirk. Reports arrival of the Company's ships the Prince and the Levant; the Eddystone later.Colony news satisfactory.His own future prospects.
to Gale. Further remarks on McLellan's trial.Coltman, a stupid and bad man. Chief Justice in favour of McLellan.
to Andrew Colvile. Enclosing the following letter.
to Selkirk. Reports the less of a packet sent to Montreal by Roderick McKenzie.Gives a summary fo the contents.
to James Stewart. Referring to his management of Lord Selkirk's lands. Describes his activities and the state of the property.
Recognizance in the Court of the King's Bench.
to Capt.Roderick MacDonell. Account of his journey from England,and Red River affairs.
to Lady Selkirk. Thanking her for a present to their chuld,her Godson.

to Selkirk. Refers to a former letter of 15 June in regard to Rainville.War party of Indians from Leech Lake overpowered by the Sioux.Suggests a medal and flag be presented to Chief Little Corbeau for his attachment to the Company. The flag to be of silk with the Company's arms on it. A medal could also be sent to the Boundard,uncle of Wanata.
to Selkirk. Cases referred to have been transferred to Upper Canada. Warrants in the hands of Sheriffs. Has no depositions or evidence from Coltman except those of Reinhart and McLellan.
to Selkirk. Notifies him that James Grant's suit against him has been dismissed.
to John Allan. Simpson's demands for shorthand notes.
to John Charles. Reports his arrest by North West Company and the plunder of all property on 9 May,led Mr.Frobisher.
to Selkirk. Acknowledging receipt of Captain Matthey's letter of the 17th instant.
List of Scotch,Canadian and de Meuron settlers at Red River.Names and number of family given.
to J.B.Robinson. Giving information with reference to the trials to take place in Upper Canada; admittance of his counsel.
to J.B.Robinson. Asking for information as to his intentions regarding the trials to take place at York.
to Selkirk. Defending himself from various charges and reports made against him.
to Selkirk. Regarding Chief Justice Sewell's distortion of testimony on McLellan's trial.Captain Otty,R.N. on his way to Montreal.Becher going to West Indies for promotion.
to James Bird. Informing him of further acts of aggression by the North West Company.Copies of correspondence with Colin Robertson enclosed.
to J. Mure. Regarding Colonel Robertson's concerns with Thomas Marsh and balance due from Hudson's Bay Company.
to D.S.Kennedy. Instructions for forwarding letters.Forwards two copies of Hudson's Bay Company Charter as it may be required at Montreal.
to J.B.Robinson. Transmitting an attested copy of information laid before him in April at Sandwich, regarding a charge of felony against Lord Selkirk,himself and others.
to Selkirk. Replying to his of 14 August regarding Prince Edward Island affairs. Advises him to sell all his land on the Island.No further collection of quit rents to take place.
to Morris J.Muller. Forwards a Power of Attorney regarding the Salmon River lands.
to LeMoine, (French.) Letters received. Movements of canoes. The road to Lac La Pluie.
Deposition taken before W.B.Coltman.
to Gale. McLellan acquitted by petit jury;but placed under bail for £1000 for murder of Governor Semple.

to Selkirk. Describes his journey and arrival after fifteen days of fog and windy weather. Death of Miss Spencer,and illness among members of the brigade.Suggests a visit from Sir John Johnston would prove beneficial in dealing with the Indians. Reports on progress of the Settlement.Lemoine erecting a large cross near the blockhouse and another at the churchyard.
to de Graffenried. Account of proscratination of law proceedings in the two provinces.Regrets he cannot be relieved until after Matthey's trial.

to Selkirk. Refers to character of Mr.Jones;considers him unsuitable for employment at Red River. Budge,in command of a trading post,very satisfactory.Patrick McNaulty and family anxious to settle at Red River.Regrets the loss of Mr.Greely and four men,but has no particulars as yet.
